author: wired blogs
text: date: thu, 23 dec 1999 07:37:26 +0000 from: harry irvine (hei123@earthlink.net)to: newsfeedback@wired.comsubject: overvalued ipothis is a comment on joanna glasner's "most overvalued ipo" article ("and the most overvalued ipo is...," 23.dec.99). i am not a so-called investor, i say, so-called, because when all is said and done you could substitute the term speculator instead of investor. i think that these ipos become so overvalued because most of the drive behind today's so-called investing is the "last fool theory."if you have never read about the financial bubbles of the days of yore, you should look up data on an outstanding one in holland called tulip mania, or sometimes tulipamania. greedy people operating on the last fool theory bid up the price of tulip bulbs as they could always sell them for more than they paid for them. at the end of the mania, tulip bulbs were going for astronomical prices. then someone realized that what can you do with a tulip except look at it, and the price of tulip bulbs fell over night, taking their economy with it.what a hoot. perhaps the best thing a so-called investor can do now is to cash out, use the proceeds to buy some land they can grow things on, and ride out the coming storm, after all the other boobs realize that all this dot com junk is a few computers and maybe a warehouse, and the value of all their ipo stocks becomes worthless.
